habitat_description:
This species is only known to occur in the drainage of the Kings River and in the western slope of the Sierra Nevada in Fresno County, California (Jockusch et al. 1998; Stebbins 2003). Recently, populations of this species were reported in the Middle Fork Kaweah River at 610m of elevation in Sequoia National Park in Tulare County (Jockusch and Wake 2002). Egg deposition sites are presumably associated with talus and may be laid deep underground in rock and litter. This species is associated with wet margins of seasonally flooded meadows, thus eggs may be laid under moist or decaying logs.
Habitat in the Kings River drainage is characterized by mixed, pine-oak, and chaparral associations. Vegetation in these areas includes interior live oak, foothill pine, western redbud, California bay, western sycamore, and blue oak (Jockusch et al. 1998). There is a report of a high elevation occurrence in moist coniferous forest of lodgepole pine and red fir (2470m; Lannoo 2005; Green et al. 2013). 

Coniferous forest at mid to high elevations.
